description:
Shamans possess mysterious powers that allow them to commune with gods, spirits, and even the dead…and Manta Oyamada's about to learn all about them, because his class just welcomed a new transfer student: Yoh Asakura, a boy from way off in Izumo…and a shaman in training!

(Source: Kodansha USA)

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Ghost
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a ghost.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Mythology
tags.description: Prominently features mythological elements, especially those from religious or cultural tradition.

tags.name: Primarily Child Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters below a high school age.

tags.name: Twins
tags.description: Prominently features two or more siblings that were born at one birth.

tags.name: Reincarnation
tags.description: Features a character being born again after death, typically as another person or in another world.

tags.name: Environmental
tags.description: Concern with the state of the natural world and how humans interact with it.

tags.name: Primarily Male Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of male characters.

tags.name: Kuudere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who generally retains a cold, blunt and cynical exterior, but once one gets to know them, they have a very warm and loving interior.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

node.description:
__Height:__ 158 cm

__Non-anime roles:__
- Juri Wu Nien in "Gundam Seed: Alliance V.S. Z.A.F.T." (PSP) (Japanese)
- Lois Lane in "Superman: The Animated Series" (Japanese)
- Melanie in "Tales of Legendia" (VG) (Japanese)
- Selena Restall in "Super Robot Wars Alpha 3" (VG/PS2) (Japanese)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/takeimokei) | [Wiki (EN)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hiroyuki_Takei) | [Wiki (JP)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%AD%A6%E4%BA%95%E5%AE%8F%E4%B9%8B) Hiroyuki Takei is a Japanese manga artist, best known as the creator of the multicultural hit, [Shaman King](https://anilist.co/manga/30050/). Hiroyuki Takei started drawing manga with writer EXIAD on SD Département Store Series which they created for a fanzine. Early in his career, in 1992, he became the assistant to [Tamakichi Sakura](https://anilist.co/staff/142555/) on [Shiawase no Katachi](https://anilist.co/manga/96332/) and [Kouji Kiriyama](https://anilist.co/staff/114838/) on [Ninku](https://anilist.co/manga/41361/). At that time, he also submitted his first yomikiri Dragdoll Group to the Tezuka Award but was rejected. Two years later in 1994, he submitted his short story Anna the Itako to the 48th Tezuka Award and won the honorable mention. He was later introduced to [Nobuhiro Watsuki](https://anilist.co/staff/96890/) and became his assistant along with [Eiichirou Oda](https://anilist.co/staff/96881/) on [Rurouni Kenshin](https://anilist.co/manga/30022/). Takei published his short story Death Zero in Weekly Shounen Jump winter special and Butsu Zone in the summer special of 1996. A reworked version of [Butsu Zone](https://anilist.co/manga/33539/) became his first manga series published in Weekly Shounen Jump of 1997. Takei's longest-running series, Shaman King began serialization in Shueisha's Weekly Shounen Jump in 1998, though was forced to conclude in 2004. In 2007, Takei returned three years after the conclusion of Shaman King with a new WSJ series; [Jumbor Barutronica](https://anilist.co/manga/31495/). The series was canceled after ten issues and released in one volume. During the Jump Festa 2008, Shueisha announced a kanzenban reprint of Shaman King. This release reprinted the entire series in 27 volumes complete with new covers while concluding the never-before-published "true ending." On March 4, 2008, it was announced that Takei would be collaborating on [Karakuridouji Ultimo](https://anilist.co/manga/36941/) with renown American comic creator [Stan Lee](https://anilist.co/staff/100048/). The project launched with the new Jump Square Second spinoff manga magazine on April 18, 2008. On February 15, 2017, when answering a fan's question, Hiroyuki Takei revealed on his official Twitter that he received an offer for an anime remake of his representative work Shaman King, but had to turn it down because they were not able to use the first anime's voice actors and soundtrack music. Though, on June 12, 2020, the official Shaman King manga website announced that the manga is inspiring a [brand-new television anime](https://anilist.co/anime/119675/) that will premiere April 2021. It is set to adapt all 35 volumes of the manga’s new complete edition. Takei was also recently interviewed in a [Youtube video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zp6_kvcEI_4) by Archipel. (Sources: Wikipedia, Anime News Network)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/oichanmusi) | [Bluesky](https://bsky.app/profile/oichanmusi.bsky.social) | [Website](https://hifumi-inc.co.jp/team/mizushima-seiji/)

After graduating from Tokyo Designers' Gakuin College, Mizushima joined [Tokyo Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/899/). While doing photography work at the beginning of his career he studied under director of photography [Masahiro Kumagai](https://anilist.co/staff/174419/). He later went to work for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) as a production assistant, aiming to become a full-fledged director.

Mizushima debuted as an episode director in 1993 on [Kouryuu Densetsu Villgust](https://anilist.co/anime/2049/), aiding the director of the OVA [Katsuhiko Nishijima](https://anilist.co/staff/103059/). In 1998, he made his proper directorial debut with [Generator Gawl](https://anilist.co/anime/1022/). He has since gone on to direct numerous shows, among which [Shaman King](https://anilist.co/anime/154/), [Fullmetal Alchemist](https://anilist.co/anime/121/) and [Oh! Edo Rocket](https://anilist.co/anime/2152/).

He often cites [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/) as an anime director that he respects.
Birthplace: Tokyo, Japan Website (artist page) Oomori Toshiyuki is a Japanese composer, arranger, pianist and musician.

Akio Takami is an animator, animation supervisor and character designer. Originally a member of Ashi Productions, he joined Xebec in the 90s, where he participated in most of Xebec's works and became one of the key people at the studio.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Sunma47) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/三間雅文)

One of the industry's most prolific sound directors, having worked on more than 300 productions.

After having graduated college, Mima joined Magic Capsule, a sound production company ran by his relative [Susumu Aketagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/120062/). In 1986, he debuted as a sound director on [MD Geist](https://anilist.co/anime/1285/MD-Geist/). He left Magic Capsule in 1996, and later joined Techno Sound. In 2004, he became the studio's representative director.

[Wiki (pl)](https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wojciech_Bujoczek)

Vocalist for the metal band Killjoy.
_Note: Not to be confused with the [animator](https://anilist.co/staff/130391/)._

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/oichanmusi) | [Bluesky](https://bsky.app/profile/oichanmusi.bsky.social) | [Website](https://hifumi-inc.co.jp/team/mizushima-seiji/)

After graduating from Tokyo Designers' Gakuin College, Mizushima joined [Tokyo Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/899/). Mizushima debuted as an episode director in 1993 on [Kouryuu Densetsu Villgust](https://anilist.co/anime/2049/), aiding the director of the OVA [Katsuhiko Nishijima](https://anilist.co/staff/103059/). In 1998, he made his proper directorial debut with [Generator Gawl](https://anilist.co/anime/1022/). He has since gone on to direct numerous shows, among which [Shaman King](https://anilist.co/anime/154/), [Fullmetal Alchemist](https://anilist.co/anime/121/) and [Oh! Edo Rocket](https://anilist.co/anime/2152/).

He often cites [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/) as an anime director that he respects.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/31969571)

Originating from [Aubec](https://anilist.co/studio/6090/).

_Note: Not to be confused with the [other director](https://anilist.co/staff/242744/) by the same name._
